physDesc.p: The letter consists of 4 sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides. At the top of each sheet (every other page) there is a page number in the center, with the exception of the first page. In several places, there is inserted type between lines. The last page has a piece torn from the side that does not meaningfully interrupt text.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: Here’s your draft for payment in full, I believe; at least I think it is as full as the cheque was. They have just sent it to me this morning, and I am hastily getting it off to you. Do not say I have not done your business well, for I certainly did slave to get them to pay in the beginning, and then, when I had to return the cheque, I sweated blood for fear they would dock it when they put it into a draft; but here you are, safe and sound, and don’t make any scruples about taking it. It is legally and ethically yours by every possible account.

I feel so dreadfully about that number of “The Egoist” that I lie awake at night. It is a shame that all those good articles should be lost, not really lost, of course, for you have your own distribution, but not circulated by us. But I know Ferris is right when he says it would be folly to do it. You must try and believe that we do know our public over here, and that you have not any real intimacy with them as a public, and we know the way it is likely to jump.

I haven’t had any answer to my cable sent you yesterday, and when I took the trouble to pre-pay it, I think that is a little queer. I don’t want you to write that refutation of Monro’s remarks on me. I know you can, out of the very things you said in your review of me. You see, as none of the poems in regular metre, which you do not like (at least you don’t like mine) appear in the Anthology, and as you seemed to like all these poems when they were shown to you, you ought not to have much difficulty in saying something which shall at once down Monro’s sneer and be true to your own principles.

Yours and Harriet’s correspondence has caused me a little sigh of despair. I think you are both wrong. I think it is foolish to protest against reviews, although I have just written a letter to Monro himself; but I felt at liberty to do so, because he pitched into me about my “London Letter” last Autumn. On general principles, I am sure reviews should always pass unnoticed, whether they are good or bad, and she would have a much more efficient way of getting back at you by simply never accepting any more of your poems for her magazine. That is what I think the majority of editors would do, and it speaks well for Harriet’s singleminded devotion to poetry that she prefers to squeal on paper and run the risk of a snub, rather than hurt her magazine by refusing your poetry or being unjust to you as a poet. That is pretty fine of her. Of course, I do not like her poetry any more than you do, or rather that is not quite fair, I think there were points about “The Hotel,” as you said yourself, and there was a dirge about a little nephew of hers who died which, if old-fashioned in expression, was extremely sincere in feeling. I am sorry that you and Harriet should get at odds, because she does try so hard to make her magazine good; and I must say, when you take the whole thing straight from the first issue to the last, as I had occasion to do the other day in connection with my talk on modern poets, it is a fact that there is no poet in the English-speaking countries of any note whose work has not been printed in her pages. I bet a hat that is more than any other magazine can boast.

I think in everything in this world, even in art, even in business, one should not lose one’s sense of the amenities of life. I remember your counseling me this way when Ezra wrote that terrible letter to Macmillan in the Autumn. I followed your advice and have never regretted it. Harriet is a poor woman, with hardly enough money to live upon, on the wrong side of middle age. She is lonely and exceedingly unattractive. Her one consolation in life is to believe herself talented. It is frightfully pathetic, and is a subject in which Balzac or Maupassant would have revelled. Would it hurt you, who are young, vigorous, and have a future before you, to have done what we call “letting her down easy”; and would it have done any serious harm to those artistic principles in which you believe? I do not think it would have, and I do believe in always remembering the good English pugilistic rule that in fighting you must take a fellow of your own size. What has struck me so much in my studies of the French poets this winter, is the extraordinary courtesy with which they treat each other. I do not think our literary life is overflowing with courtesy, and it is a jolly bad thing for our poetry that it is not.

I think that your contention that Harriet should have written to you, as an editor, through the columns of your paper, is (pardon me) ridiculous. We all write personal letters to editors which are not meant for publication, and they are never ignored, but always answered again privately, as letters between two individuals should be. I see no reason why you should print her poem, I think she is foolish to ask you to, and you certainly cannot recant your criticism in your own paper, and I think the suggestion that she write to you is a very good one. But I think a little air of “bonhomie” strewn over your relations would grease the wheels and do no harm to anybody. It is none of my business to give you advice, of course, but since you sent me the correspondence, I thought I would tell you how I feel about it.

I do wish you and Hilda could come over here this summer, as I cannot get over there. Would you consider coming if I could get you a translating job to keep you while you were here? The Boston Music Company, one of the branches of the largest publishing firm in America, and the people who issued yours and Rummel’s book, have a lot of song translating to do. It is rather fussy, because it has to be done to music already written. I have done an awful lot of it, so I know its difficulties; but it is not uninteresting work, and they pay $5.00 a poem and up. They always have a great lot on hand, and they applied to me for names of people who can do it. Fletcher has just done six poems for them, and I have no doubt I could get you some work of that kind, if you care to come over. Then you could stay permanently or not, as you choose. I do think a sojourn in America, whether long or short, would be an interesting thing for you, and I think you would learn and awful lot about this country which you never suspected. If the idea appeals to you, let me know, and I will see what can be done.

I was sorry about Sadler’s books, but please realize that every one of the 150 copies that Constable ordered have already been paid for. They own them; we do not. They are marked on our list as already sold. I hope that, if they dispose of them all, they will send for some more; and I should keep in pretty close touch with Sadler, if I were you. They left here in a freight boat on the 16th of April straight to London, and when they got over, they had to have new title pages put in and be bound, so it is not surprising that they did not come before. I know Sadler is thoroughly interested in the movement and, if you talk over your various schemes with him, I think you will find him willing to cooperate, if you make him think that you are co-partners in a common cause, and do not push him.

They have sent me the revised list from Houghton Mifflin to-day, in which it appears that Ferris Greenslet’s original figures were wrong, and that our sale up to date, including the advance copies, is 460 copies.
